ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .

The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Jeffrey James Stoike  See below for my assessment of the TA.
Instructor: Jeffrey James Stoike  Jeff was awesome -- laid back, really smart, and always helpful. He taught me some very applicable ways of sorting through the dense material of this class.
Instructor: Jeffrey James Stoike  Jeff was very helpful in all of my interactions with him.
Instructor: Jeffrey James Stoike  Jeff was great!

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I just loved this class. Carol is great, and the subject matter is really interesting and really important.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: I found the readings helpful and interesting if a bit repetitive and concise. I would have appreciated the opportunity to read a few of the authors at greater length and to have less repetition (for example, we read chapters from Ferguson's The Anti-Politics Machine on three separate occasions, rather than devote a week to that important work).
The readings are very great, and Carol's dissection of them was always helpful.

I love the structure of Carol's courses âÂ lecture followed by student-led discussion; weekly thesis sentences; comparative analyses twice during the semester. The topic was also fascinating and mind-blowing, and my brain was overwhelmed for the first little while but got more used to it. Carol is really good about answering questions as they arise, and providing feedback and guidance at office hours.
Discussing the readings during class.
The readings are super interesting, and Carol's very thorough explications are great. Her classes always make me think very critically and question my assumptions.

The progressive readings and thinking behind the topics. How economic/political history and anthropology offer great insights how our economy became the way it is today and the price of it and how all of this relates to the environment.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: I thought it was VERY repetitive to have the professor spend approximately two hours per week lecturing on the exact points the authors we read discussed. As graduate students, I would hope we would be expected to be able to understand what we are reading, at least at a basic level, without having to rely on the professor walking us through it (and through her own very particular interpretations) each week. This was a repetitive formula and a very slow pace for a graduate course. Lectures would have been much more interesting had the professor expanded on that week's reading or given further case studies or even opened up the floor for a longer student conversation (seminar style) of the material.I also found the professor a bit one dimensional. Perhaps this was due to the repetitive, even redundant, teaching style described above or my own personal dissatisfaction with a Yale professor who seemed so bound to the confines of Foucauldian anthropological interpretations and her own personal background/field work to the point where she gave the impression of a lack of curiosity or interest in other disciplines, regions of the world, etc.
The 3-hour weekly class format made it hard to stay focused at times.
This course was perfect!

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Most weeks the lectures (which I have above described as repetitive, even redundant) took up the majority of the class time and we only had roughly 30 minutes remaining for discussion. I would have liked to see this ratio a little less lopsided. I feel like I gained a lot from the readings, very little from the lectures, and a fair amount from the often too-brief discussions.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Jeffrey James Stoike  Jeff's lecture on his own fieldwork the last week of class was very interesting and I thought he did a nice job in its presentation.I was a little bit puzzled by his responses to some of the class's written work in which he critiqued student's ideas always in the less personal "we" as in "we thought...", "we felt...", "we interpret Gudeman...", etc. While some element of agreement with the professor is to be expected I wondered if he had any of his own ideas or if he was simply regurgitating the professor's opinions. I'm not sure if this is a critique more suited to the TA or to the professor.Finally, and this is not at all a critique of Jeff or the professor but rather of the structure of the course within F&ES, I find the use of a graduate student as a TA in a class with graduate students to be a bit awkward. I'm not particularly comfortable with essentially a peer giving me a grade. Maybe some of the seniors and first year graduate students in the class felt differently about this, however. In my opinion, peer critiques and peer comments are almost always helpful but the situation is a bit awkward when they are assigned the task of grading my work.

Instructor: Jeffrey James Stoike  Jeff was awesome! Very available to talk and work through things. Good at helping figure out what some of the more cryptic authors were saying. Any logistics were invisible. Helped me think new things about my research, too!
Instructor: Jeffrey James Stoike  I think discussion in class could have been improved with Jeff's involvement.
Instructor: Jeffrey James Stoike  Jeff was very helpful, and responded quickly to questions via email. He also gave a compelling lecture, and was helpful in preparing for discussions.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Despite some of my critiques above, I did find this to be a very helpful course, largely due to the important readings assigned.
This course is very relevant to my work, at least insofar as economic questions are an inevitable part of understanding why small farmers make the choices they do.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To get deeper exposure to some of the fundamental work on development and conservation. To that end, this course met that expectation. I might suggest a different style or presentation but I certainly did find the course material valuable.
I took this course because I hate capitalism and wanted to strengthen my understanding of why I hate it.
I endeavor to take every class of Carol's possible, plus I was really interested in learning to think critically and analytically about the Economy.
Because Carol is one of my favorite professors, and I knew the course would be interesting and would cover important and relevant material.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: For the most part. See above.
More than I ever could have imagined.
Yes, and exceeded!

Yes! I feel much better able to think critically about economic issues at this point, especiallywith regard to conservation and development, and I'm more aware of the role that these issues play in my own research.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Only take this course if you are unfamiliar with the authors on the syllabus. It is a nice survey of some important fundamental texts but the professor doesn't do much other than rehash what you read that week so don't expect much beyond a useful chance to shore up some gaps in your reading.
Give the readings the time they need and come with questions! Carol has answers.
This is a great course. Carol is really wonderful, and the subject matter is interesting and really relevant if you're interested in any kind of conservation or development work.
